title: Canonical layouts
description: Ready-to-use compositions that help layouts adapt for common use cases and screen sizes.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Use the three canonical layouts as starting points for organizing common elements in an app.

Each layout considers common use cases and components to address expectations and user needs for how apps adapt across window class sizes and breakpoints.
Resources

Type
Resource
Status
ImplementationMDX-Android – Canonical layoutsAvailable
Flutter – Adaptive scaffoldAvailable
Jetpack Compose –  Adaptive layoutsAvailable
Takeaways

• There are three canonical layouts: List-detail, supporting pane, feed
  • Each canonical layout has configurations for compact, medium, and expanded window size classes
Layouts

Feed

Use a feed layout to arrange content elements like cards in a configurable grid for quick, convenient viewing of a large amount of content.

contentChunks.footer: Example feed layout

contentChunks.htmlValue:
List-detail

Use the list-detail layout to display explorable lists of items alongside each item’s supplementary information—the item detail. This layout divides the app window into two side-by-side panes.

contentChunks.footer: Example list-detail layout

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Supporting pane

Use the supporting pane layout to organize app content into primary and secondary display areas. The primary display area occupies the majority of the app window (typically about two thirds) and contains the main content. The secondary display area is a panel that takes up the remainder of the app window and presents content that supports the main content.

contentChunks.footer: Example supporting pane layout

contentChunks.htmlValue:
A feed layout uses a grid composition to enable quick content browsing and discovery.

Key use cases for the supporting pane layouts include:

  • News
  • Photos
  • Social media

contentChunks.footer: Photo app using a feed layout

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Use a feed layout to show different pieces of content through cards and lists.

Feeds support displays of almost any size as grids can adapt from single to multi-column.

contentChunks.footer: Example news apps using a feed layout for compact and medium window size classes

contentChunks.htmlValue: Dividing space
A feed composition is flexible enough to allow for content with varying proportions and sizing.

contentChunks.footer: Example feed layout with two columns

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Use size and position to establish relationships among content elements.

Feed items should reflow when the amount of available space changes, such as rotating or unfolding a device, or entering a multi-window mode. 

The order of items is determined by their position. Learn more: Cards responsive layout guidance

contentChunks.footer: News app with a feed layout using two columns

contentChunks.htmlValue: Across window size classes

Compact

  • A feed layout stacks vertically like a list of cards, with individual items taking up the width of the pane, but not necessarily the full height

contentChunks.footer: Cards in two feed layouts for compact window size class

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Medium

  • A feed layout can support components with different widths and be split across multiple columns

contentChunks.footer: Navigation bar and cards in a feed layout for medium window size class

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Expanded

  • A feed layout can support components with different widths and be split across multiple columns. The number of columns of content should usually increase for expanded window size classes.

contentChunks.footer: The number of columns increased from two to three in the expanded window size class

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Feed items should reflow when the amount of available space changes, such as rotating or unfolding a device, or entering a multi-window mode. The order of items is determined by their position. Learn more: Cards responsive layout guidance

Many layouts can be established based on the relationship of a list and a detail view.

Key use cases for this layout include parent-child pairings of information like:

  • Text message + conversation
  • File browser + open folder
  • Musical artist + album detail
  • Settings + category detail
  • Email inbox + selected email

contentChunks.footer:
1. List 
  2. Detail

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Use the list-detail view for displaying browsable content and quickly showing details.

Examples include: showing a series of conversations and a text message; browsing files and seeing their details; or browsing multiple albums and seeing individual track information in an adjacent view.

contentChunks.footer:
Simplified diagram of:

  1. List area
  2. Detail area

contentChunks.htmlValue: Dividing space

contentChunks.footer: The most basic list-detail views for compact, medium, and expanded layouts

contentChunks.htmlValue:
A list-detail view uses two panes: one for a list or group of items and the other for a detailed view. Depending on the window class, the two panes may appear together in the same layout or across separate layouts.

List-detail canonical layouts use the same pane guidance as all single and two-pane layouts, including special behavior for foldables.

Window size class (dp)Visible panes
Compact (0-599)1 pane
Medium (600-839)1 (recommended) or 2 panes
Expanded (840+)2 panes
Across window size classes

Compact

  • Use a single-pane layout
  • Only one view is visible at a time (either list or detail)

contentChunks.footer:
1. Phone in portrait orientation
  2. Closed foldable
  3. Tablet in split-screen mode

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Medium

  • Use a single-pane layout for information-dense content or longer interactions

contentChunks.footer:
1. Foldable open flat
  2. Tablet in portrait orientation

contentChunks.htmlValue:
• Use a two-pane layout for information-dense content, or quicker interactions
  • To avoid cramped pane widths, use a bottom navigation bar or modal navigation drawer with two-pane layouts in medium only

contentChunks.footer:
1. Foldable open flat
  2. Tablet in portrait orientation

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Expanded

  • Use a two-pane layout

contentChunks.footer:
1. Phone in landscape orientation
  2. Tablet in landscape orientation

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Single vs two-pane

  • Up button: Appears in detail view only for single-pane layouts
  • Selected state: Appears only in list view for two-pane layouts
  • Visual focus: Use explicit and implicit grouping to direct focus in two-pane layouts

contentChunks.footer: Two-pane layout and single pane layout

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Transitioning between layouts

The amount of available space is dynamic and changes based on user behavior, such as rotating or unfolding a device, or entering a multi-window mode.

contentChunks.footer: A two-pane list-detail layout adapts to a one-pane layout when the device is rotated, changing from expanded to medium window class.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
From single to two-pane layout:

If list pane is visible: Detail pane appears showing a placeholder state (ie. no item selected)

contentChunks.footer: If no item in the list view is selected when a foldable is opened, the revealed pane displays an empty detail view.

contentChunks.htmlValue: If detail pane is visible: List pane and currently selected detail pane appears. The list pane now shows the state of the selected item.

contentChunks.footer: If an item in the list is selected when a foldable is opened, the revealed pane displays that item’s detail view.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
From two-pane to single pane layout:

If a list item is currently selected: The detail pane remains visible and the list pane hides, top app bar appears.

contentChunks.footer: If an item in the list is selected when a foldable is closed, the list view is hidden and the detail view is shown in the single pane.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
If no list item is selected: List pane remains visible and detail pane hides.

In some use cases, such as multi-select, the pane last interacted with should remain visible.

contentChunks.footer: If no item in the list is selected when a foldable is closed, the detail view is hidden and the list view is shown in the single pane.

contentChunks.htmlValue: In most cases, state should be saved when navigating between detail views. Detail views with read and unread content fall into this use case.

contentChunks.footer: The scroll position of a detail view is retained even after navigating to other list items.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Contents
Usage
Dividing space
Across window size classes

The supporting pane layout organizes content into primary and secondary areas. 

The primary area occupies the majority of the body area and contains the main content. The secondary area contains supporting content.

Key use cases for supporting pane layouts include:

  • Productivity
  • Document editing and commenting
  • Content and media browsing

contentChunks.footer: The supporting pane layout organizes content into primary and secondary areas.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Use the supporting pane layout when the secondary content is only meaningful in relation to the primary content. 

For content with a parent-child relationship, use a list-detail view layout instead.

contentChunks.footer: Simplified diagram of a supporting pane layout

contentChunks.htmlValue: Dividing space

The screen is divided between a focus pane and a supporting pane.

Depending on the window size class, the supporting pane may appear below or beside the focus pane.

contentChunks.footer: Diagram of a supporting pane positioned below the primary focus area

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Supporting pane placementPane widthWindow size class
BelowFlexibleCompact or Medium
Left-side or right-sideFixed (360 dp)Expanded
Across window size classes

Compact

  • The supporting pane should appear below the focus pane
  • A bottom sheet can be useful for keeping focus on the primary pane while providing access to supporting information

contentChunks.footer: Supporting pane below the primary focus pane in compact layouts

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Medium

  • The supporting pane should appear below the focus pane

contentChunks.footer: Supporting pane below the primary focus pane in medium layout

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Expanded

  • The supporting pane should appear on the left or right side of the focus pane

contentChunks.footer: Supporting pane at the trailing end of the primary focus pane in expanded layouts

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Contents

Resources

Supporting panel
Feed
Canonical layouts are available for mobile, foldable, and tablet devices.

contentChunks.footer: Canonical layout examples.

Learn moreMaterial Blog – Prepare your app for large screensAvailable
About canonical layouts

Canonical layouts are large screen compositions that serve as starting points for design and implementation. Use the three available layouts to organize common elements in an app. 

Each layout considers common use cases and components, addressing user needs for how apps adapt across screen sizes and breakpoints.

Navigation on large screens
  • Use a navigation rail rather than a navigation bar or bottom app bar on large screens (600dp+ width). Many tablets, foldables, and desktop devices already include a system task bar at the bottom of the screen, so applications with bottom navigation create a double-bar effect which has poor usability.
List-detail view

Many layouts can be established based on the relationship of a list and a detail view. The relationship is established spatially by taking the left side of the screen to display a list and the right side to show the list's detail. This can be used in landscape orientation only. In portrait mode, consider a layout adjustment. 

Key use cases for the list-detail view layouts include pairings of information such as:

  • Text message + conversation 
  • File browser + open folder 
  • Musical artist + album detail

When to use

The list-detail view is best for browsing content and quickly seeing details. 

It supports information hierarchies that can adapt for larger screen sizes. 

Examples include: showing a series of conversations and a text message; browsing files and seeing their details; or browsing multiple albums and seeing individual track information in an adjacent view.

contentChunks.footer: A messaging app showing a list of people and their individual conversations.
contentChunks.altText: A messaging app showing a list of people and their individual conversations

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Dividing space

A list-detail view uses two columns: one for a list or group of items and the other for a detailed view.

contentChunks.footer:
1. List area
2. Detail area
contentChunks.altText: 2 columns, left side in list view, right side in detail view

contentChunks.htmlValue: In a list-detail layout, on smaller window sizes an app can divide the list and detail areas equally. For large window sizes, the layout area can be divided asymmetrically.

contentChunks.footer: Left: List-detail layout on a foldable device; Right: List-detail layout scaled up to a tablet.
contentChunks.altText: Smaller foldable screen on left, tablet screen on right, with detail space split asymmetrically.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Device and size applications

The list detail layout is best suited for landscape orientations; see below for a breakdown of their recommended use in different window sizes.


Breakpoint range (dp)
Portrait
List detail
Landscape

Foldable

Recommended

Foldables: 1:1 layout

On foldables, divide content across a device hinge into two equal areas to show a list and the detail view without disruption.

contentChunks.footer: Mail app using a 50/50 screen division
contentChunks.altText: Screen display divided in half

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Fixed and flexible column layout

On foldable devices, apps can also divide the screen using a fixed column width for the list and a flexible width for the detail view. This division of areas can be used if the list view content can be read comfortably.

contentChunks.footer: Message app using 1:2 screen division
contentChunks.altText: Screen view split into one-third and two-thirds

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Large screens

Continue to divide the screen using an asymmetrical proportion. This division maintains the hierarchical relationship of your content between a list (supporting information) and a detail view (focus).

contentChunks.footer: Tablet messaging app using asymmetrical layout proportions.
contentChunks.altText: Foldable device screen showing list and detail content in asymmetrical layout.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Top app bars can be placed inside of detail containers.

contentChunks.footer: A top app bar inside of a detail view seen mid-scroll.
contentChunks.altText: Top app bar set inside detail container

contentChunks.htmlValue: When switching to portrait mode on a foldable device, it's best to use a single-column layout to comfortably flow content across the narrow dimension of a screen.

contentChunks.footer: Use a single column layout in portrait mode.
contentChunks.altText: Single column set in portrait layout

contentChunks.htmlValue: If you choose to use a list-detail layout for a foldable device's portrait mode: ensure that adequate space is provided for list items to be easily read.

contentChunks.footer: Ensure there's enough space in portrait mode to make list items easy to read.
contentChunks.altText: List view showing space for content

contentChunks.htmlValue: When moving from landscape to portrait modes and a list item is selected: show the detail view of the selected item following the transition to portrait mode.

contentChunks.footer: When transitioning from landscape (left) to portrait (right), show the list view in a single panel if the user has made a selection from the list.
contentChunks.altText: Single panel showing list view

contentChunks.htmlValue: If the user hasn't made a selection, return to the list view on portrait mode when switching orientation.

contentChunks.footer: Show the list view in a single panel on portrait if the user hasn’t made a selection from the list.
contentChunks.altText: Single panel showing list view

contentChunks.htmlValue: Supporting panel

The supporting panel layout is a method for extending a screen. Supporting panel layouts are different from list-detail view layouts because the primary and secondary focal points are considered equally important and integral to each other, simultaneously.

This layout is suited for devices with a seamless hinge. 

Key use cases for the supporting panel layouts include:

  • Productivity 
  • Document editing and commenting
  • Content and media browsing

When to use

The supporting panel layout creates a relationship of focus and support. The layout uses a container that occupies two-thirds of the screen and is paired with a supporting panel that occupies the remaining space.

contentChunks.footer: An explicit container or focus panel occupies two-thirds of the screen while a supporting panel occupies the remaining space.
contentChunks.altText: A composition using a document in the focus panel, and related comments on its supporting panel

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Dividing space

The screen is divided between a focus panel (left) and a supporting panel (right).

contentChunks.footer:
1. Focus panel
2. Supporting panel
contentChunks.altText: creen divided in an asymmetrical proportion by setting a fixed width for the supporting panel, and a fluid width for the focus panel.

contentChunks.footer: Supporting panel composition scaling between a phone, foldable and a tablet devices.
contentChunks.altText: supporting panel compositions shown on several device sizes from phone, to foldable, to tablet device.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Device and size applications

The supporting panel layout is best suited for landscape orientations. Below is a breakdown of recommended uses for different window sizes.

For foldable devices with a physical hinge, it's best to split the screen into equal halves, using one half as the supporting panel.

Tabs can support navigation between content types in a panel.

contentChunks.footer: If a device has a physical hinge, a composition can take one panel as the focus, while the other panel shows supplementary or supporting information.
contentChunks.altText: Document shown in focus panel with related comments on supporting panel

contentChunks.htmlValue: On more compact displays, the supporting panel can be positioned below the focus panel.

contentChunks.footer: An app in portrait mode can stack the focus panel above the comments carousel in its own panel. Note: The toolbar shown on the navigation rail is not available in code and is shown here as a design exploration only.
contentChunks.altText: Document app showing the focus panel on top, comments below

contentChunks.htmlValue: When adapting a supporting panel layout for a tablet, the focus panel should be larger than the supporting panel.

contentChunks.footer: A supporting panel layout using a larger focus panel.
contentChunks.altText: Tablet device showing larger focus pane on left, smaller supporting panel on right.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Feed

Feeds are a common layout for news and social content. Feeds use a grid composition to enable content browsing and discovery. 

On mobile and foldable devices, the same interactions and composition can be applied. For example, opening an item opens a new page. 

On foldables, however, the feed can be designed as a more immersive view because of the larger screen size.

When to use

A feed layout can be used to show different pieces of content through cards and lists. 

Feeds often support content-driven experiences, such as news or photos.

contentChunks.footer: Showing various pieces of content through cards and lists, a feed layout supports content discovery and browsing.
contentChunks.altText: A composition using a news feed.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Dividing space

Components like cards, lists, and banners provide multiple entry points into app content.

contentChunks.footer: Feed area is highlighted as a group of components and elements, such as cards and list items.
contentChunks.altText: A feed layout showing differing content

contentChunks.htmlValue: A feed composition is flexible enough to allow for content with varying proportions and sizing.

contentChunks.footer: Feed composition scaling between a phone, foldable and a tablet device.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Device and size applications

The feed composition works well on all device orientations. Below is a breakdown of recommended uses for different window sizes.

The feed allows content components to expand across multiple columns. This expansion takes advantage of the added space a larger screen provides.

contentChunks.footer:
Expanding content into numerous columns creates an improved layout for a large screen.

components expand over multiple columns, creating a layout optimized for a large screen.
contentChunks.altText: A detail of a card that expands over multiple columns in layout

contentChunks.htmlValue: On a tablet, a feed layout can support components with different widths and be split across multiple columns.
